text: [Music]
I think one of the hardest things that
we've got at the New Yorker to to to
sustain and to keep bettering is humor I
um I think I once took Roger Angel out
to lunch Roger is a writer who's been at
the magazine for a very very long time
he's in his
80s and I said you know Roger I've been
doing this now for a couple of years and
it's easier for me to get somebody to go
sleep on the ground in Sudan ban and
Dodge bullets in Afghanistan that it is
to get something authentically
funny and he nodded and he said well
that's very interesting because you are
now the fifth editor of the New Yorker
to tell me this beginning with Harold
Ross and it's true it's true not that
being a foreign correspondent or or or
dealing with danger is is any small
thing but humor at the highest level uh
whether it's Saul Steinberg or SJ
Pearlman or or David Sedaris or whatever
uh is a very very rare rare thing now as
far as cartoons are concerned you deal
with the cartoons that come in and then
select among those and I work very
closely with Bob manof the cartoon
editor in doing that uh a difficult
thing there is getting young
cartoonists um we have any number of
cartoonists who are of um middle a age
late middle age and older but it's tough
to make a living as a Cartoonist I think
a lot of the people that might think of
becoming a
cartoonist uh do other
things which are hell of a lot more
remunerative uh we have some cartoonists
who are in Hollywood like Bruce Eric
Kaplan um somebody like Ros Chast is
able to do what she does and do more
with it in the art world and in the
humor world uh but it's a tough gu
it's a tough go
[Music]
